author: By Nicholas Casey
title: Pastors at the Polls? Meet Ohio’s Election Protection Squad
description: After the most tense election season in generations, clergy members are being trained and deployed to defuse potentially violent encounters on Election Day.
content: From across Ohio, ministers, chaplains and social workers who have volunteered to deploy to the polls dialed in to a videoconference to hear nine hypothetical situations they might encounter on Election Day, from people refusing to wear masks to politicians pressuring those in line to vote for them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor, Jesse McKinley, Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Sydney Ember, Annie Karni, Stephanie Saul and Dave Montgomery
title: Trump defends Texas drivers who surrounded Biden bus, while the president’s supporters block traffic in New York and New Jersey.
description: The battle for the presidency is hitting the road.
content: The battle for the presidency is hitting the road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Amazon, HBO Max, Hulu and More in November
description: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are our picks for November.
content: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of November’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: Inside One Brooklyn Restaurant’s Desperate Fight to Survive the Pandemic
description: Half of New York City’s 24,000 restaurants could go out of business. Gertie is fighting to avoid becoming one of them.
content: On the second Saturday in March, the owners of Gertie, a Jewish-American luncheonette in Brooklyn, finalized a last step in the makeover of their year-old restaurant. They hired a new sous chef, an up-and-comer who had landed hours before on a one-way flight from Detroit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: She’s Moved From the Upper East Side to ‘Cobble Hill’
description: Cecily von Ziegesar, the author of “Gossip Girl,” is going for an adult, possibly Brooklyn-based audience in her new novel, but there will still be drama.
content: The inspiration for Cecily von Ziegesar’s latest novel? Lice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: ‘Bob Ross Experience’ Opens in Indiana, Happy Trees and All
description: Visitors can tour the beloved painter’s recreated studio and take Bob Ross master classes, in the city where “The Joy of Painting” was filmed.
content: MUNCIE, Ind. — Lexi Vann was losing her race with Bob Ross.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger
title: Americans Are Afraid. Not for Themselves, but for the Country.
description: A feeling of alarm and fear about the future of democracy, from voters across the political spectrum.
content: There is much to fear this year, as campaign speeches and ads remind voters. The virus is surging, hospitals are filling again, and children are falling behind in school. Renters risk eviction, and businesses remain boarded up. Violent crime has risen and could reach your neighborhood, the president warns. And in this unsettling time, you could lose your health care, your job, your property values, or your local police department.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Nikki McKibbin, ‘American Idol’ Finalist, Dies at 42
description: Ms. McKibbin, who finished third on the inaugural season of the reality talent show in 2002, died on Sunday after a brain aneurysm, her husband said.
content: Nikki McKibbin, a singer-songwriter from Texas best known for her third-place finish on the inaugural season of “American Idol,” died on Sunday. She was 42.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Tracing Now All but Impossible as Outbreaks Tear Through U.S.
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 1, 2020.
content: “You can swing a cat and hit someone who has got it.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham
title: Preaching or Avoiding Politics, Conservative Churches Walk a Delicate Line
description: Pastors can’t endorse or oppose candidates from the pulpit, and many of them don’t want to. But that doesn’t mean they’re ignoring politics.
content: The second weekend in October was “citizenship weekend” at Prestonwood Baptist Church in Plano, Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Can Raphael Warnock Go From the Pulpit to the Senate?
description: The pastor at the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta, where Martin Luther King Jr. once preached, is betting that Georgia is ready to send a religious progressive to Washington.
content: DALTON, Ga. — On a recent Sunday morning in northwest Georgia, the Rev. Raphael G. Warnock, the South’s most prominent Black preacher and a Democratic candidate for the U.S. Senate, was giving his stump speech, mixing a little laid-back pulpit humor with a searing, Jeremiah-like condemnation of Republicans in the age of Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Larry Diamond
title: I’m a Democracy Expert. I Never Thought We’d Be So Close to a Breakdown.
description: Our election systems were not built for the modern era. Looking abroad might help.
content: As this Tuesday’s consequential election nears, my fellow democracy experts and I have often been asked: What is the right historical analogy to America’s current crisis? The truth is, there is no precedent. We have never seen such a longstanding democracy in such a rich country break down before — never. But it could happen this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Patrick Mahomes and Chiefs Pile Onto Jets’ Woes
description: Kansas City cruised with the former Jets running back Le’Veon Bell barely needing to exert himself to extend his former team’s losing streak to eight straight.
content: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Patrick Mahomes did just about everything for the Kansas City Chiefs on Sunday. He even toted Tyreek Hill back to the sideline after a touchdown catch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: On ‘S.N.L.’, Jim Carrey Reads a Spooky Election Update of ‘The Raven’
description: Carrey appeared in his recurring role as Joe Biden in a Halloween episode hosted by the “Saturday Night Live” alum John Mulaney and featuring the Strokes as the musical guest.
content: On a Halloween night that fell on a fraught weekend before Election Day, a nation turned its lonely eyes to John Mulaney, the “Saturday Night Live” alum whose return appearances to this sketch show are usually a good omen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Our Most Dangerous Weeks Are Ahead
description: We are making preparations for the election to descend into bedlam.
content: The weeks following the election could very well be the most dangerous weeks in this country since the Civil War.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Steelers’ Unbeaten Streak Comes Down to Ravens’ Last, Best Play
description: Pittsburgh rallied from down 10 at the half to take a lead on Baltimore. That’s when Lamar Jackson and the Steelers’ defense collided.
content: Of the 256 games played every N.F.L. regular season, two — and only two — are as reliably entertaining as they are vicious and close, enriched with enmity, malice and a healthy dose of respect. They are the games between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Baltimore Ravens, A.F.C. North border feuds that teem with after-the-whistle skirmishes, out-of-bounds hits and postseason implications, year after year after year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Dishonesty Has Defined the Trump Presidency. The Consequences Could Be Lasting.
description: Whether President Trump wins or loses on Nov. 3, the very concept of public trust in an established set of facts necessary for the operation of a democratic society has been eroded.
content: WASHINGTON — Born amid made-up crowd size claims and “alternative facts,” the Trump presidency has been a factory of falsehood from the start, churning out distortions, conspiracy theories and brazen lies at an assembly-line pace that has challenged fact-checkers and defied historical analogy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Larsen
title: What Happens if Neither Trump Nor Biden Concedes?
description: Our system offers many offramps from the road to disaster. Whether we take one is another question.
content: With a president refusing to commit to a peaceful transition of power, a number of commentators have been sounding the alarm about a “rickety” U.S. electoral system seen as uniquely vulnerable to a postelection crisis. Legal scholars and a group called the Transition Integrity Project have been examining the ways in which the machinery could fail, and the nightmare scenarios gamed out are hair-raising. But while looking at points of possible legal failure is a useful exercise, it neglects an important question: Who has the power to concede?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Don’t Eat the Breakfast Cereal. It’s Made of Plastic.
description: Robin Frohardt has turned a vacant space in Times Square into a colorful installation that slyly doubles as an eco-warning. Puppets have their moment, too.
content: Wrapping around a corner in Times Square, the storefront had been hidden in plain sight since the tail end of winter, when so much of the city’s creative life shut down, locked up and headed home to wait out the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Homemade Hamburger Helper, tomato soups and grilled cheese sandwiches: Fill your days with comfort.
content: Good morning. Time has been passing in the most extraordinary ways since the pandemic retired my commute in March. The days ran together until they were all one endless Wednesday, or Monday, never a weekend, which would then arrive like an occasional gift, only to disappear in what seemed like seconds. And now, suddenly, it’s November? Time to talk about Thanksgiving. I’ve avoided it long enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christy Harmon
title: Got Worries? Make Newspaper Dolls to Catch Them
description: Whispering your fears to these little dolls made of rolled newspaper might help you sleep better.
content: There’s a lot to worry about these days. With Covid-19 cases rising, the new darkness of standard time and the election taking place in a few days, everyone could use an extra outlet to release some anxiety. It’s the perfect week to turn your newspaper into a handful of worry dolls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: The Atlantic Retracts Ruth Shalit Barrett Article on Niche Sports
description: Ms. Barrett had been a rising young political reporter in the 1990s before accusations of plagiarism derailed her career as an associate editor at The New Republic.
content: The Atlantic on Sunday took the extraordinary step of retracting an article by Ruth Shalit Barrett, who was a rising young political reporter in the 1990s when accusations of plagiarism derailed her career as an associate editor at The New Republic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery and Maggie Haberman
title: Vehicles flying Trump flags try to force a Biden-Harris campaign bus off a highway in Texas.
description: Vehicles flying Trump flags tried to force a Biden-Harris campaign bus off a highway in Texas. Trump chuckled about it at a rally later that evening.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — Multiple vehicles bearing Trump flags and signs surrounded a Biden-Harris campaign bus heading from San Antonio to Austin on Friday, forcing campaign officials to scrap two campaign events, according to reports by Democratic officials on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gene Luen Yang
title: Kids’ Graphic Novels That Turn the Superhero Genre on Its Head
description: Bright, bold and utterly unconventional, both “Mister Invincible” and “Primer” flout all the “rules.”
content: When I was a kid, my local comic shop was in a strip mall about 10 minutes away from my home. It was one of my favorite places in the world. For 60 cents, I could buy a comic book — a ticket to a universe populated by modern-day gods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: ‘We’re in for a whole lot of hurt.’ Fauci’s comments infuriate the White House.
description: He has been dragged into both campaign debates, where President Trump misrepresented his positions on the pandemic. He has been featured prominently — and out of context — in a Trump re-election ad. And he has been openly derided by his own boss as a “disaster.”
content: He has been dragged into both campaign debates, where President Trump misrepresented his positions on the pandemic. He has been featured prominently — and out of context — in a Trump re-election ad. And he has been openly derided by his own boss as a “disaster.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery and Nick Corasaniti
title: Texas Supreme Court Denies G.O.P. Push to Throw Out 127,000 Votes
description: The Republican effort to invalidate the votes from Harris County, which includes Houston and is largely Democratic, now hinges on an effort at the federal level, where a hearing is set for Monday.
content: The Texas Supreme Court on Sunday denied an effort by Republicans to throw out more than 120,000 votes that had already been cast at drive-through locations in Harris County, leaving Republicans’ only remaining option at the federal level.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Why Are Republicans So Afraid of Voters?
description: There is no “both sides do it” when it comes to intentionally keeping Americans away from the polls.
content: As of Sunday afternoon, more than 93 million Americans had cast a ballot in the November elections. That’s about two-thirds of the total number of people who voted in 2016, and there are still two days until Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano and Adriana Balsamo
title: This Election Week, Revisit the Constitution, Then Soothe Your Stressed Mind
description: Calm your nerves with a meditation guide, a night at the Seattle Symphony and a day among the sea otters at the Monterey Bay Aquarium.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: David Henry Hwang’s ‘M. Butterfly’ Followup: ‘M. Turkey’
description: The goal: a comedy about mistaken racial identity inspired by protests over “Miss Saigon.” The result: a backstage farce that never got to opening night.
content: David Henry Hwang’s “Face Value” arrived on Broadway on March 9, 1993. It left five days later. For Gina Torres, an actress in that production, the news came as a relief. “Because we were pushing that stone uphill for a good long time,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Glanz
title: Tests Show Genetic Signature of Virus That May Have Infected President Trump
description: The White House did not take basic steps to investigate its outbreak. We worked with geneticists to sequence the virus that infected two journalists exposed during the outbreak, providing clues to how it may have spread.
content: President Trump’s illness from a coronavirus infection last month was the most significant health crisis for a sitting president in nearly 40 years. Yet little remains known about how the virus arrived at the White House and how it spread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: He Already Saw the Election as Good vs. Evil. Then His Tractor Burned.
description: In Nebraska, President Trump’s supporters hope he wins a second term, and that they get four more years of feeling like the country’s leader understands and defends them.
content: HENDERSON, Neb. — Jonathan Rempel has never been a loudmouth around town about his politics, but his views are clear when he asks rhetorical questions like, “Have you ever got a job from a poor person?” Or when he says that taxes are a form of extortion. They show up on Facebook, where some of his posts support gun rights and criticize a welfare state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar and Shaila Dewan
title: Ahead of Election, Police Prepare for Violence and Disruption
description: Many law enforcement officials have attempted to inject calm while warning of dire consequences for those who try to disrupt voting.
content: The Las Vegas Police had a quandary. They were on high alert for election-related threats, but when long lines of voters began snaking down streets and around parking lots two weeks ago, they feared that stationing patrol cars outside polling stations might drive people away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth D. Herman
title: Two Women and 10,000 Miles on the Road to Suffrage
description: Mapping a 1916 journey on the road to the 19th Amendment that has been largely overlooked.
content: With the 2020 presidential election now upon us, Americans are still mired in uncertainty. But at least one thing has already been made clear: The women’s vote will be critical to the outcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: Signs Get Snatched, Kicked, Burned as Political Battle Reaches the Front Lawn
description: Fights over political signs happen every year, but this year seems more intense. “It feels like a war,” one resident said.
content: CHICAGO — In Illinois, Florida and Arizona, police officers have been summoned to investigate Biden signs set ablaze and Trump flags swiped in the night. Homeowners, angry over their campaign signs disappearing, have set up elaborate motion-activated cameras to catch the culprits. A sneaky few have booby-trapped signs with sharp razor blades glinting underneath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Assessing Goni, the 18th typhoon to hit the Philippines this year.
content: After weeks of resisting calls for a lockdown, Prime Minister Boris Johnson is shutting pubs, restaurants and most retail stores in England, starting on Thursday until Dec. 2. Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland had already put in place such restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Adam Nagourney
title: Welcome to November. For Trump, the October Surprise Never Came.
description: Trump’s hope that an economic recovery, a Covid vaccine or a Biden scandal could shake up the race faded with the last light of October.
content: President Trump began the fall campaign rooting for, and trying to orchestrate, a last-minute surprise that would vault him ahead of Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Confessore, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Trump, Venezuela and the Tug-of-War Over a Strongman
description: How a yearslong battle over U.S.-Venezuela relations aided President Trump’s campaign in Florida — and left the Maduro regime standing.
content: When President Trump turned to the Capitol gallery during his State of the Union speech in February to recognize Venezuela’s young opposition leader, Juan Guaidó, it seemed like a political masterstroke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: For Australians, geographic isolation is now something to embrace.
description: They used to call it “the tyranny of distance.”
content: They used to call it “the tyranny of distance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Katie Glueck
title: Trump is visiting five states on Sunday, while Biden focuses on Pennsylvania.
description: President Trump is visiting five states on Sunday, as Joe Biden focuses his attention on Pennsylvania.
content: With less than 48 hours remaining before Election Day, President Trump was jetting across the country on Sunday to bring his closing message to five states, while Joseph R. Biden Jr. planned to concentrate his efforts in the crucial swing state of Pennsylvania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Catherine Porter
title: Famed Iranian Artist Under #MeToo Cloud Faces Art World Repercussions
description: In Iran, an exhibit of Aydin Aghdashloo’s work was canceled and a prominent auction is considering dropping him. In Canada, a petition calls for an art festival to cut ties with him.
content: A famous and well-connected Iranian artist who has been accused by at least 13 women of sexual misconduct is starting to see signs of repercussions in the art world that once exalted him, both in Iran and Canada, where he has dual citizenship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Jason Gutierrez
title: A Typhoon Spared the Philippine Capital. Will Manila Be So Lucky Next Time?
description: With climate change heightening the Philippines’ risk of natural disaster, the country is braced for the next catastrophe.
content: BANGKOK — The Philippines was braced for the worst. When Typhoon Goni made landfall in the disaster-plagued nation on Sunday morning, with sustained winds of 135 miles per hour, it ranked as the most powerful storm to hit the Southeast Asian nation in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez and Tamir Kalifa
title: In Texas, the Polls Open for a Graveyard Shift
description: Hoping to make voting easier during the pandemic, officials opened several polling sites in Harris County, Texas, for overnight balloting last week. Thousands showed up.
content: HOUSTON — Felix Sylvester drove straight to the polling site after work and cast his ballot in a matter of minutes. There was no line, perhaps because it was a few minutes past 3 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Made a Bust
description: Luke Vaughn gets artsy.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes you really have to stare at a crossword puzzle to make the theme visible, even on a Monday. Newer solvers might not know to look at different parts of the theme entries to see what they have in common, and with no revealer, they might finish the entire puzzle without realizing that there is a theme there at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Thomas Kaplan
title: Both Candidates Agree: Trump’s Crowds Are Bigger, and They’re OK With That
description: While President Trump still thrills to the roar of a crowd, even during a pandemic, Joe Biden has found a new way to get audience feedback: through honking horns at his drive-in rallies.
content: WASHINGTON — For President Trump, the only thing that really matters is the size of his crowds. For Joseph R. Biden Jr., the road to the White House is full of honking cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
title: Election at Hand, Biden Leads Trump in Four Key States, Poll Shows
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. leads President Trump in Pennsylvania, Florida, Arizona and, by a wide margin, in Wisconsin, according to a Times/Siena College poll.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. holds a clear advantage over President Trump across four of the most important presidential swing states, a new poll shows, bolstered by the support of voters who did not participate in the 2016 election and who now appear to be turning out in large numbers to cast their ballots, mainly for the Democrat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Trump is counting on efforts to target potential supporters who sat out in 2016.
description: The president’s campaign to identify likely supporters among people who did not vote in 2016 is seen by Democrats as a threat in Pennsylvania in particular.
content: As Democrats fret their way into the final hours of the race for the White House, one possibility is high on the list of reasons President Trump might win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: In Italy, Like Everywhere the Virus Goes, It’s the Discontent That’s Contagious
description: Italians are now a long way away from the days of singing on balconies and their summer fling with freedom. Just like everyone else, they’ve had it.
content: ROME — When the coronavirus first hit Italy, overwhelming the country’s hospitals and prompting the West’s first lockdown, Italians inspired the world with their resilience and civic responsibility, staying home and singing on their balconies. Their reward for months of quarantine was a flattened curve, a gulp of normalcy and the satisfaction of usually patronizing allies pointing to Italy as a model.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Enzo Mari, industrial designer who kept things simple, dies at 88.
description: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Taylor
title: In San Francisco, Virus Is Contained but Schools Are Still Closed
description: A debate over reopening classrooms pits the mayor against the Board of Education, cutting across class, party and racial lines.
content: As a third wave of coronavirus infections has begun to take off across much of the country, San Francisco has been a bright spot. After experiencing a surge of cases over the summer, the city has tamped down infections to near their lowest levels since the pandemic began. Restaurants, movie theaters, and museums are open at 25 percent of capacity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: To Trump, ‘the Polls That Matter’ Point to Victory. The Rest Are ‘Fake.’
description: President Trump’s blinkered view of 2020 polling has created something of an alternate universe, even as his campaign struggles to find the voters he needs in the data it has.
content: When President Trump talks about polling, his focus is very much on survey-takers that he thinks are good for him. Polls that show him trailing Joseph R. Biden Jr. — virtually all national polls — are simply “fake news.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Trump moves Florida rally up by two hours, but it could still run afoul of a local curfew.
description: A Trump rally planned for late Sunday in Florida could run afoul of a local curfew.
content: MIAMI — President Trump’s fifth and final rally on Sunday in Opa-locka, Fla., was moved to 9:30 p.m. after being scheduled to kick off at 11:30 p.m., a late hour for attendees and viewers — and a potential problem for local officials. To try to slow the spread of the coronavirus, Miami-Dade County has a nightly curfew that begins at midnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Kelly
title: Listen to the Globe
description: Radio programming from around the world is available on the internet or through apps.
content: Americans may not be able to travel the world because of the pandemic, but thousands of foreign radio stations are easily accessible online to bring the world to you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Najim Rahim and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Deadly Taliban Attack Probably Used Drone, a Worrisome Shift
description: The strike targeted the governor’s compound in Kunduz, a province that has seen heavy fighting despite peace talks between Taliban and Afghan government negotiators.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — A Taliban attack, most likely carried out by a drone, killed at least four security officers in northern Afghanistan on Sunday, according to senior and local Afghan officials, representing what could be the group’s first publicly known use of the method in the 19-year war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano
title: Don’t Give In to ‘Election Stress Disorder’
description: Voting day won’t bring an end to the strain of this political season, but you don’t have to let things get contentious.
content: From the droves of people voting by mail to the widespread protests for racial justice to the pandemic and worries about the electoral process itself, the 2020 election cycle provides “a recipe for a lot of angst” on Election Day, according to Alvin Bernard Tillery Jr., a professor of political science at Northwestern University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Dispute Over Pissarro Painting Looted by Nazis Is Back in Court
description: A Holocaust survivor wants to revisit a settlement with an Oklahoma art museum over a painting once owned by her father.
content: When Léone Meyer discovered in 2012 that a painting Nazi looters had stolen from her father was in the collection of an American museum, her first instinct was to demand its return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: A Nail-Biter
description: The election’s outcome will shape the economy — and your wallet — for years to come.
content: It’s basically impossible to talk about anything but the election, but here goes. (And if you haven’t voted yet, use today’s extra daylight saving hour to make a plan for the polls.) See you on the other side. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘He Managed a Smile and Thanked Charles for the Compliment’
description: A reunion with a well-dressed teacher, a tricky census question and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Dwight Garner Shares From His Stash of Other Writers’ Words
description: In an excerpt from his new book, “Garner’s Quotations: A Modern Miscellany,” the Times critic explains why he’s hoarded favorite lines for nearly 40 years and why he’s sharing some with readers now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: How J Balvin Made His Trippy, Eye-Popping Halloween Concert in Fortnite
description: The video game has become a music venue as the pandemic continues to keep live shows off the road. The Latin pop star put his own colorful spin on the experience.
content: For J Balvin’s big entrance on Saturday night in his concert appearance on the video game Fortnite, the Latin pop star rose through a giant glowing pumpkin, just as he might emerge from the bowels of Madison Square Garden on a lift to meet thousands of screaming fans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina
title: ‘They’re coming after our state,’ McSally warns Arizona Republicans.
description: SUN CITY, Ariz. — Don’t believe the polls. Don’t believe the media. And definitely do not believe the Democrats.
content: SUN CITY, Ariz. — Don’t believe the polls. Don’t believe the media. And definitely do not believe the Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: How the Wealthy World Has Failed Poor Countries During the Pandemic
description: Despite pledges for debt relief and expanded programs, the World Bank and International Monetary Fund have delivered meager aid, say economists.
content: LONDON — Like much of the developing world, Pakistan was alarmingly short of doctors and medical facilities long before anyone had heard of Covid-19. Then the pandemic overwhelmed hospitals, forcing some to turn away patients. As fear upended daily life, families lost livelihoods and struggled to feed themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Tropical Storm Eta Forms, Tying a Record Set 15 Years Ago
description: Eta became the 28th named storm of the 2020 hurricane season, matching a record set in 2005.
content: Tropical Storm Eta, the 28th named storm of a fiercely active hurricane season, churned over the Caribbean on Sunday, gaining strength as it headed west toward Central America, the National Hurricane Center said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Voting System in Maine Threatens Collins in Final Days of Close Senate Race
description: The state’s new ranked-choice system could prove dangerous for Senator Susan Collins, who is running for a fifth term against Sara Gideon, a Democrat.
content: CUMBERLAND, Maine — Sara Gideon, her voice hoarse on a cold Friday night, stood in the center of a fairgrounds stage as the headline act at a drive-through rally, making a closing pitch to a chorus of appreciative car honks and headlight flashes for a government dominated by Democrats that would move aggressively to address climate change, economic and racial inequality and out-of-control health care costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: 2 Warehouse Halloween Parties Attended by Nearly 1,000 Are Shut Down
description: Few people were social distancing or wearing masks, New York City authorities said. Twenty-eight people face charges.
content: Two Halloween parties with hundreds of guests dancing and drinking inside warehouses were broken up by New York City authorities this weekend, as officials strive to curb behavior that they worry could fuel a second wave of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: Why You Can’t Rely on Election Forecasts
description: Voting models are not as scientific or certain as they may seem.
content: If we’re worried about getting drenched on the way to work, we take a look at what meteorologists’ computer models say about the weather. If the weather report tells us there’s an 80 percent chance of rain, we bring an umbrella.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Halloween Stabbing Attack in Quebec City Leaves 2 Dead
description: The police arrested a 24-year-old man who they said was dressed in medieval garb and carrying a sword when he went on a rampage.
content: MONTREAL — The police in Quebec City said on Sunday that they had arrested a man dressed in medieval garb and brandishing a sword after a series of stabbings on Halloween night left two people dead and five others wounded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: In Russia’s Idyllic Wine Country, Dark Tales of Dreams Dashed
description: A verdant slice of southern Russia evokes Tuscany and produces surprisingly magical wine. But bureaucratic nightmares and police raids intrude on the aspirations of upstart vintners.
content: ANAPA, Russia — Russia has no shortage of innovators, risk-takers and freethinking entrepreneurs. But their country is not built for them. Sooner or later, the state security apparatus makes its unwelcome appearance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: Trump, Biden and the Tough Guy, Nice Guy Politics of 2020
description: The 2016 election was a referendum on many things, including what Americans thought a woman could do or be. Now it’s a question of what a man should be.
content: Kindness. Humility. Responsibility. These traits were once “the definition of manliness,” Barack Obama told a crowd on Saturday, campaigning in Flint, Mich., for his former running mate, Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Meet the Ebony Anglers, Five Black Women Catching Fish and Stares
description: The team, formed in the past few months, is trying to make a mark in the mostly white, mostly male world of competitive fishing.
content: ATLANTIC BEACH, N.C. — The shooting stars that illuminated the dark sky on the journey to deeper waters had given way to a crisp morning when Gia Peebles felt her fishing rod tense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 2, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: The New York City Marathon Was Canceled. Runners Ran the Course Anyway.
description: The 50th New York City Marathon would have been Sunday. Some runners still ran the 26.2-mile course despite the cancellation.
content: The New York City Marathon began on Oct. 17, technically at least.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Caregivers Have Witnessed the Coronavirus’s Pain. How Will They Vote?
description: In Pennsylvania, deaths in nursing homes account for almost two-thirds of all virus-related fatalities. Some of the people working inside those facilities say the pandemic is shaping their politics.
content: At the Pennsylvania long-term care facility where Tisheia Frazier works, the coronavirus was a terror. During the most harrowing weeks of the pandemic in April and May, she said, four residents died in a matter of hours, and 70 people in an 180-bed unit died in less than a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: We Have Never Had Final Results on Election Day
description: President Trump has been trying to pre-emptively delegitimize ballots counted after Nov. 3. But states have always counted past election night.
content: For weeks, President Trump and his allies have been laying groundwork to challenge the results of the election if he loses. Now, in the final days of the campaign, he has settled on a blatantly ahistorical closing argument: that the votes in a fair election should not be counted past election night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kay Nolan
title: In chilly Milwaukee, young canvassers go door to door.
description: Amira Randolph, 15, and about 25 other young people braved strong wind and near-freezing temperatures on Sunday to encourage people in Milwaukee’s Near South Side to turn out and vote. Wearing masks, the canvassers stepped back six feet after ringing doorbells.
content: Amira Randolph, 15, and about 25 other young people braved strong wind and near-freezing temperatures on Sunday to encourage people in Milwaukee’s Near South Side to turn out and vote. Wearing masks, the canvassers stepped back six feet after ringing doorbells.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: Mississippi City Spared Loss of Electric Service
description: Upset over high electricity bills, residents of Itta Bena, Miss., complained, only to discover the city was hundreds of thousands of dollars in debt to its power supplier.
content: Seeing a $450 to $600 electricity bill no longer fazes Patricia Young of Itta Bena, Miss., a city of about 1,800 people in the Mississippi Delta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Florida City’s Beloved Swans Find New Homes
description: Lakeland, Fla., held a lottery to sell some of its 86 swans, which have thrived since Queen Elizabeth II donated a pair in 1957.
content: The buyers traveled from all over Florida, with crates and carriers, to bring their feathered guests home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: Tap LinkedIn for Career Opportunities
description: Whether you’re looking for a new role or just trying to expand your professional network, here’s how to use the website’s services to your full advantage.
content: Arguably the least fun social media platform, LinkedIn used to be the online equivalent of a professional networking event — a stodgy affair that no one really wanted to hang around. But, for the foreseeable future, the pandemic has all but eradicated most other methods of sniffing out career opportunities. Now that grabbing drinks with former colleagues or hobnobbing at work conferences is off the table, LinkedIn has been promoted from obligatory to essential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 8 of the N.F.L. Season
description: Dalvin Cook shredded the Packers, the Steelers stayed undefeated and Joe Burrow and the Bengals shocked Tennessee.
content: A Packers home loss to lowly Minnesota. Pittsburgh toppling the Ravens in Baltimore to stay undefeated. The Dolphins and the Bengals pulling off wild upsets behind rookie quarterbacks. The theme of Week 8 was to expect the unexpected, though the Jets proved to be a stabilizing force by losing to Kansas City in as ugly a fashion as predicted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Celebrities lend Biden a hand in turning out the vote in Philadelphia.
description: PHILADELPHIA — Add Debra Messing and Kathy Najimy to the thousands of canvassers spread out across Philadelphia for the Biden campaign on Saturday.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Add Debra Messing and Kathy Najimy to the thousands of canvassers spread out across Philadelphia for the Biden campaign on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Antonella Francini
title: Poets and Lovers: Do Rimbaud and Verlaine Belong in France’s Panthéon?
description: A petition seeks to honor them, but critics ask if it’s about poetry or sexuality, and whether such rebels would be out of place in an august shrine to national heroes.
content: PARIS — “To the great men, a grateful homeland” reads the inscription above the columned entrance to the Panthéon, France’s storied tomb of heroes, which houses the remains of idols like Hugo, Curie and Rousseau.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin, Patricia Mazzei and Astead W. Herndon
title: Inspiring Black Voters Is Key to Biden’s Prospects in Florida
description: Democratic groups are pouring money into get-out-the-vote efforts in Black precincts to try to increase turnout from 2016, in a state that is critical to President Trump’s re-election chances.
content: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — One Saturday last month, after Democrats held a news conference in this city’s predominantly Black east side to promote the start of early voting, State Senator Audrey Gibson offered her view about why turnout among Florida’s African-Americans dropped so strikingly in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: U.S. Diplomat Coughs Online, and European Allies Wonder if They Were Exposed
description: A senior State Department official who tested positive for the coronavirus after a trip to Europe has angered other diplomats and irritated foreign officials whom he could have infected.
content: WASHINGTON — As part of a diplomatic tour through Europe in late October, the State Department’s director of policy planning briefed journalists in London about the Trump administration’s strategy toward China. A video of the virtual event showed him coughing at least six times during the hourlong discussion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Obituaries for the American Dream
description: If it was ever real, it isn’t anymore.
content: We’ve been talking about “the American dream” since James Truslow Adams coined the phrase in his 1931 book, “The Epic of America.” But what’s a dream anyway? A brimming over of the day’s repressed desires? Just a flutter of the neurons? If the American dream was ever real, it isn’t now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Kamala Harris, Mass Incarceration and Me’
description: Many progressives mistrust her for her past as a prosecutor. For Reginald Dwayne Betts — an ex-convict and the son of a crime victim — it’s not that simple.
content: At 16, Reginald Dwayne Betts was sent to prison for nine years after pleading guilty to a carjacking, to having a gun, and to an attempted robbery.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 1, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 1, 2020.
content: An interview on Sept. 27 about Ilhan Omar, the Democratic congresswoman from Minnesota, referred incorrectly to her family’s arrival in the United States in 1995. They came to the United States as refugees. They were not granted asylum status.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: After coughing, a State Department official met with European diplomats. Then he tested positive.
description: As part of a diplomatic tour through Europe in late October, the State Department’s director of policy planning briefed journalists in London about the Trump administration’s strategy toward China. A video of the virtual event showed him coughing at least six times during the hourlong discussion.
content: As part of a diplomatic tour through Europe in late October, the State Department’s director of policy planning briefed journalists in London about the Trump administration’s strategy toward China. A video of the virtual event showed him coughing at least six times during the hourlong discussion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Make Some Noise and Move: A Choreographer Provides Instructions
description: “I really didn’t want it to be about the screen,” Yanira Castro said about adapting a work for the pandemic. Instead, she made scores to try at home.
content: About 50 people sat in front of their computers on a recent afternoon, banging on pots and pans with kitchen utensils. In a departure from common Zoom etiquette, everyone was unmuted and making as much noise as possible. What began as an attempt to find a synchronized beat quickly unraveled into clanging, joyful chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: On Marathon Weekend, Des Linden Ran 26.2 Miles, and Then Some, in New York
description: The New York City Marathon turned into a virtual event, but that did not stop Des Linden from coming to New York to accomplish something big.
content: This was not the way Des Linden was planning to finish a marathon in Central Park this weekend, when she and 50,000 other runners were supposed to run the New York City Marathon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: When parents lose their jobs, children suffer. But sometimes there’s a consolation.
description: Nearly 22 percent of children in the United States had an unemployed parent in April, the highest rate on record, according to Zachary Parolin, a researcher at Columbia University.
content: Nearly 22 percent of children in the United States had an unemployed parent in April, the highest rate on record, according to Zachary Parolin, a researcher at Columbia University.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: 8 Pro-Democracy Politicians Arrested in Hong Kong Over Heated Meeting
description: The Hong Kong politicians were arrested in connection with a contentious meeting in May, when the local legislature’s chambers were filled with protest over a battle for control over a key committee.
content: HONG KONG — The police arrested seven pro-democracy politicians early Sunday over a heated meeting in May, when the local legislature’s chambers were filled with protest over a battle for control over a key committee. An eighth was arrested Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Courtney Rubin
title: Learn the Etiquette of Virtual Weddings
description: The answers to all your 2020 pandemic wedding dilemmas.
content: With weddings this year being delayed, downsized or split into two — video ceremony now, party next year — many guests have some only-in-2020 etiquette questions. Should you dress up? Send a present — or two? Read on for answers to all your pandemic wedding quandaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Judith Levitt
title: Coronavirus Surge, Election Day, Sean Connery: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: With just two days until Election Day, all eyes are on Pennsylvania.
description: All eyes are on Pennsylvania, which both presidential campaigns seem to believe could determine the outcome of the race.
content: As the election winds to a close, President Trump and Joseph R. Biden Jr. are converging on Pennsylvania, with both candidates holding a flurry of events in a last-minute quest for votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Rescuers Race Against Time to Find Survivors After Quake in Turkey
description: After the deadly tremor rocked the country’s western coast, razing buildings in the city of Izmir and killing dozens of people, hope began to fade for some of those still trapped under the rubble.
content: The death toll from a major earthquake off the coast of Turkey reached at least 62 on Sunday, with more than 900 others injured, as rescuers continued to dig through tons of rubble in the city of Izmir in the diminishing hope of finding more survivors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Vinciguerra
title: Sean Connery: From Tentative Secret Agent to Suave Bond
description: He may be considered the ultimate 007, but it took him time to find his footing, helped by a director with a taste for high living.
content: In 1965, at the height of James Bond mania, Sean Connery told Playboy magazine that he had no problem with another actor assuming his signature role. “Actually, I’d find it interesting to see what someone else does with it,” he said. “Lots of people could play him.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh and Lucy Tompkins
title: How are Americans catching the virus? Increasingly, they have no idea.
description: When the coronavirus first erupted in Sioux Falls, S.D., in the spring, Mayor Paul TenHaken arrived at work each morning with a clear mission: Stop the outbreak at the pork plant. Hundreds of employees, chopping meat shoulder to shoulder, had gotten sick in what was then the largest virus cluster in the United States.
content: When the coronavirus first erupted in Sioux Falls, S.D., in the spring, Mayor Paul TenHaken arrived at work each morning with a clear mission: Stop the outbreak at the pork plant. Hundreds of employees, chopping meat shoulder to shoulder, had gotten sick in what was then the largest virus cluster in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Billups
title: There Are Evangelicals Who Stand Against Trump. I’m One of Them.
description: We can’t succumb to the president’s appeals to fear.
content: Like many kids who grew up as evangelicals, I was taught that abortion was the only issue when it comes to politics. When I turned 18, in the 1990s, my father took me to the Allen County Republican headquarters in my Indiana town, where I registered as a card-carrying conservative. Then we went to Fort Wayne’s Famous Coney Island for celebratory chili dogs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Collins, Trip Gabriel and Stephanie Saul
title: The Battlegrounds Within Battlegrounds
description: Here are 20 counties in battleground states that are crucial for a White House victory.
content: Here are 20 counties in battleground states that are crucial for a White House victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: A Nutmegger, a Buckeye and a Sooner Walked Into a Voting Booth...
description: Every four years, as Election Day draws near, we embrace America’s oddball geographic nicknames.
content: Every four years, as Election Day draws near, we embrace America’s oddball geographic nicknames.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Nadja Popovich
title: What Voters in Battleground States Think About Climate Change
description: In key swing states, the majority of voters are worried that rising temperatures or sea levels will affect their lives. For some, it has become a voting issue.
content: In key swing states, the majority of voters are worried that rising temperatures or sea levels will affect their lives. For some, it has become a voting issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Did the Pandemic Destroy Halloween? Here’s What We Found
description: Even as the pandemic threatened to ruin Halloween, New Yorkers dressed up, they danced, they played and they even skated from morning to night.
content: Even as the pandemic threatened to ruin Halloween, New Yorkers dressed up, they danced, they played and they even skated from morning to night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Schoenfeld Walker, Lisa Waananen Jones and Jugal K. Patel
title: States Undercount Positive Rapid Tests, Masking the Spread of Disease
description: Health officials say an influx of rapid, inexpensive tests is good for the country, but caution that they are struggling to count those who test positive.
content: Health officials say an influx of rapid, inexpensive tests is good for the country, but caution that they are struggling to count those who test positive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becovic Management Group
title: Swans Find New Home in Florida
description: The city of Lakeland, Fla., held a public lottery to sell some of its 86 swans. Two of them were relocated and released into a pond at Lost Lake Apartments in Jacksonville, Fla.
content: The city of Lakeland, Fla., held a public lottery to sell some of its 86 swans. Two of them were relocated and released into a pond at Lost Lake Apartments in Jacksonville, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Let’s Get Started on Fighting Climate Change
description: Readers suggest concrete ways we can act now. Also: The nonvoter also makes a decision.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: What This Election Means for America
description: Some final thoughts about the candidates and voters’ hopes and fears as Election Day looms.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
